content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, I would choose strategy B{B} for several reasons:

1. In this game, there are two dominant strategies: R and B. If both players consistently choose the same dominant strategy (in this case, R), they will end up with the same payoff after each round. However, since I am playing against an anonymous player who may or may not have the same strategy as me, it's best to choose the strategy that yields a slightly higher payoff if they deviate from the dominant strategy.

2. Choosing B results in a better outcome for me if my opponent chooses R (35$ instead of 0$). Since there are more rounds where my opponent might choose R (75 out of 154 possible combinations), it's advantageous to choose B.

3. By choosing B, I can potentially earn slightly more than the other player if they also choose B in later rounds. In this case, since the game has 75 rounds, there is a higher chance that both players will end up choosing B multiple times due to the repetition of strategies over time. This strategy could potentially yield an average payoff slightly higher than if both players stick with R consistently.

4. Given the anonymity of the opponent, I can't assume they are rationalizing their choices in the same way as me. They might choose a different strategy or change their strategy during the game. By choosing B, I am better prepared to adapt to any potential changes in their strategy since it yields a higher payoff in more scenarios.

Overall, based on these factors, I would choose B{B} for this lab experiment.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.

As a human player, I will choose R{R} for the next round.

1. In the previous round, both my opponent and I chose B, which resulted in a payoff of 40$ each. Since we are playing this game multiple times (75 rounds), it's important to switch strategies occasionally to maximize potential gains. Switching from B to R in the next round allows me to receive a higher payoff if my opponent decides to stick with their strategy and choose B again.

2. If my opponent decides to switch their strategy from B to R, I will earn 45$ while they get only 0$. This is an advantageous outcome for me, as it results in a higher payoff compared to the previous round's payoff (45$ > 40$).

3. Since my opponent and I are playing against each other multiple times, there may be a tendency for them to anticipate my switch in strategy and adapt their own strategy accordingly. By alternating between B and R, I make it more difficult for my opponent to predict my future choices, increasing the chances of exploiting any potential deviations from optimal strategies on their part.

4. In the long run, adopting a strategy of alternating between B and R may potentially yield an average payoff that is slightly higher than sticking with only one dominant strategy (B) throughout the entire game. This is due to the fact that there are more scenarios where I can take advantage of my opponent's potential deviations from optimal strategies by choosing R when they choose B, or vice versa.

Overall, based on these factors, I would choose R{R} for the next round in this lab experiment.
